sections.title: Introduction to the Enhanced Permeability and Retention (EPR) Effect
sections.tldr: The Enhanced Permeability and Retention (EPR) effect describes a phenomenon where macromolecules selectively accumulate in solid tumor tissues due to leaky tumor vasculature and impaired lymphatic drainage. This pathophysiological characteristic allows for passive targeting of nanomedicines to tumor tissues, which has become a fundamental principle in cancer drug delivery systems. (8 sources)
sections.text:
The Enhanced Permeability and Retention (EPR) effect, first described by Matsumura and Maeda in 1986, is a pathophysiological phenomenon that enables macromolecules and nanomedicines to accumulate selectively in solid tumor tissues compared to healthy tissues <Paper corpusId="221166257" paperTitle="(Gerosa et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="232775475" paperTitle="(Kim et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>. This effect stems from the unique characteristics of solid tumors, which exhibit angiogenesis, rapid growth, and metastatic potential <Paper corpusId="13707720" paperTitle="(Wu et al., 2001)" isShortName></Paper>.

The EPR effect is primarily driven by two key mechanisms. First, tumor blood vessels develop with structural abnormalities, including deficient basement membranes and fenestrated endothelial tubes, which increase vascular permeability and allow macromolecules to leak from the bloodstream into tumor tissues <Paper corpusId="256595759" paperTitle="(Abballe et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="3163532" paperTitle="(Benjamin et al., 1999)" isShortName></Paper>. Second, solid tumors typically lack efficient lymphatic drainage systems, resulting in the prolonged retention of these macromolecules within the tumor microenvironment <Paper corpusId="235200480" paperTitle="(Matsumura, 2021)" isShortName></Paper>.

These pathophysiological properties allow macromolecular substances that normally cannot pass through healthy blood vessels to easily penetrate tumor vasculature. Additionally, once these substances enter the tumor tissue, they remain there for extended periods due to insufficient lymphatic clearance <Paper corpusId="235200480" paperTitle="(Matsumura, 2021)" isShortName></Paper>. Consequently, large molecules and nanoparticles (typically above 40 kDa) can progressively accumulate in vascularized tumor areas, providing a mechanism for passive targeting of anticancer compounds <Paper corpusId="237330183" paperTitle="(Wu, 2021)" isShortName></Paper>.

The EPR effect has become a fundamental principle in the design of nanomedicines for cancer treatment, as it enables selective drug delivery to tumor tissues through passive accumulation without affecting normal tissues <Paper corpusId="221166257" paperTitle="(Gerosa et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper>. However, it is important to note that the strength of the EPR effect varies considerably depending on tumor type, location, blood perfusion status, and the physicochemical properties of the macromolecular agents <Paper corpusId="237330183" paperTitle="(Wu, 2021)" isShortName></Paper>. Additionally, some tumors exhibit an EPR-insensitive phenotype characterized by smaller endothelial fenestrations, heterogeneous pericyte coverage, more developed vasculature, denser extracellular matrix, and more developed immune profiles, which can limit the effectiveness of EPR-based drug delivery strategies <Paper corpusId="232775475" paperTitle="(Kim et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="204826101" paperTitle="(Dhaliwal et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper>.

snippets: Matsumura and Maeda reported in 1986 that the blood vessels of the majority of solid tumors are characterized by an enhanced vascular permeability, which allows the accumulation of antitumor agents in the tumor tissue (Matsumura et al., 1986). They named this the EPR effect (enhanced permeability and retention), the mechanism by which large molecules accumulate in tumors. Based on the EPR effect, pharmaceutical nanoparticles with a higher circulation time in the blood are collected in tumor tissues with enhanced vascular permeability, and this tool is commonly used for selective drug delivery into tumors through passive accumulation. In fact, EPR drug delivery does not work on normal tissues (Torchilin, 2011).

paper.title: Gold Nanoparticles: A New Golden Era in Oncology?

snippets: The enhanced permeability and retention (EPR) effect first coined by Matsumura and Maeda (Matsumura et al., 1986) is defined the phenomenon of macromolecules or high molecular weight drug and nanomedicine accumulation inside solid tumor models compared to healthy tissue counterparts (Kalyane et al., 2019). EPR effect is usually induced by a leaky tumor vasculature by the accelerated angiogenesis and impaired lymphatic drainage by the disorganized growth of tumors (Greish, 2010)(Dhaliwal et al., 2019). In details, NPs with appropriate sizes can evade the tumor capillaries and be retained in the tumor tissues for days due to the lack of lymphatic drainage. Additionally, particles with high positive charges can bind non-specifically to the negatively charged luminal surface due to the presence of sulfate and carboxylate sugar moieties [106]

Furthermore, a key challenge is the promotion of the EPR effect in patients with EPR-insensitive tumor phenotypes since the EPR-insensitive phenotype is known to have smaller endothelial fenestrations, heterogeneously high or low pericyte coverage, more developed and branched vasculatures, a relatively dense ECR, and more developed immune profiles compared to EPR sensitive phenotypes (Dhaliwal et al., 2019).

paper.title: Recent Advances in Nanotechnology with Nano-Phytochemicals: Molecular Mechanisms and Clinical Implications in Cancer Progression

snippets: Solid tumors exhibit unique pathophysiological characteristics such as angiogenesis, rapid growth, and metastasis. Enhanced permeability of tumor vasculature allows tumor tissue to meet the great demand for nutrients and oxygen. Such enhanced permeability is thus a prerequisite for rapid tumor growth. We previously demonstrated that solid tumors have a unique characteristic of enhanced vascular permeability and retention of macromolecular and lipidic agents, which we termed the enhanced permeability and retention effect (EPR effect).

paper.title: Enhanced Vascular Permeability in Solid Tumor Involving Peroxynitrite and Matrix Metalloproteinases
paper.venue: Japanese journal of cancer research : Gann

snippets: For the first time, in 1986, Hiroshi Maeda and colleagues described the pathophysiological phenomenon that occurs in solid tumor vasculature known as the "enhanced permeability and retention effect" (EPR effect) (Matsumura et al., 1986). This mechanism describes the intrinsic ability of macromolecules to reach and accumulate in the solid tumors' interstitium, based on tumor pathophysiological characteristics such as: (i) neovascularization, characterized by deficient basement membranes and fenestrated structures of endothelial tubes, (ii) upregulation of inflammatory factors and (iii) lack of efficient drainage of lymphatic systems, that together sustain the delivery, accumulation and retention of molecules into solid tumor tissues (Benjamin et al., 1999)(Wu, 2021).

paper.title: Nanoparticles for Drug and Gene Delivery in Pediatric Brain Tumors’ Cancer Stem Cells: Current Knowledge and Future Perspectives

snippets: Features that distinguish tumor vasculatures from normal blood vessels are sought to enable the destruction of preformed tumor vessels. We show that blood vessels in both a xenografted tumor and primary human tumors contain a sizable fraction of immature blood vessels that have not yet recruited periendothelial cells. These immature vessels are selectively obliterated as a consequence of vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) withdrawal. In a xenografted glioma, the selective vulnerability of immature vessels to VEGF loss was demonstrated by downregulating VEGF transgene expression using a tetracycline-regulated expression system. In human prostate cancer, the constitutive production of VEGF by the glandular epithelium was suppressed as a consequence of androgen-ablation therapy. VEGF loss led, in turn, to selective apoptosis of endothelial cells in vessels devoid of periendothelial cells. These results suggest that the unique dependence on VEGF of blood vessels lacking periendothelial cells can be exploited to reduce an existing tumor vasculature.

paper.title: Selective ablation of immature blood vessels in established human tumors follows vascular endothelial growth factor withdrawal.

snippets: In solid tumors, there is an increase in tumor neovascularization, no corresponding increase in the lymphatic recovery system, and a marked increase in local vascular permeability. Utilizing these pathological properties, macromolecular substances that do not ordinarily leak out of normal blood vessels can leak easily from tumor blood vessels, and macromolecules that leak locally into the cancer tissue stay in place for a long time because of a lack of efficient lymphatic drainage. As a result, highly stable macromolecular substances that are not captured by the reticuloendothelial systems in the body and are not filtered from the renal glomerulus can accumulate selectively in cancer tissue. Collectively, these ideas are termed the enhanced permeability retention (EPR) effect 15 ( Figure 1).

paper.title: Barriers to antibody therapy in solid tumors, and their solutions

snippets: Chemotherapy for human solid tumors in clinical practice is far from satisfactory. Despite the discovery and synthesis of hundreds of thousands of anticancer compounds targeting various crucial units in cancer cell proliferation and metabolism, the fundamental problem is the lack of targeting delivery of these compounds selectively into solid tumor tissue to maintain an effective concentration level for a certain length of time for drug-tumor interaction to execute anticancer activities. The enhanced permeability and retention effect (EPR effect) describes a universal pathophysiological phenomenon and mechanism in which macromolecular compounds such as albumin and other polymer-conjugated drugs beyond certain sizes (above 40 kDa) can progressively accumulate in the tumor vascularized area and thus achieve targeting delivery and retention of anticancer compounds into solid tumor tissue. Targeting therapy via the EPR effect in clinical practice is not always successful since the strength of the EPR effect varies depending on the type and location of tumors, status of blood perfusion in tumors, and the physical-chemical properties of macromolecular anticancer agents. This review highlights the significance of the concept and mechanism of the EPR effect and discusses methods for better utilizing the EPR effect in developing smarter macromolecular nanomedicine to achieve a satisfactory outcome in clinical applications.

paper.title: The Enhanced Permeability and Retention (EPR) Effect: The Significance of the Concept and Methods to Enhance Its Application

snippets: The enhanced permeability and retention (EPR) effect has underlain the predominant nanomedicine design philosophy for the past three decades. However, growing evidence suggests that it is over-represented in preclinical models, and agents designed solely using its principle of passive accumulation can only be applied to a narrow subset of clinical tumors. For this reason, strategies that can improve upon the EPR effect to facilitate nanomedicine delivery to otherwise non-responsive tumors are required for broad clinical translation. EPR-adaptive nanomedicine delivery comprises a class of chemical and physical techniques that modify tumor accessibility in an effort to increase agent delivery and therapeutic effect. In the present review, we overview the primary benefits and limitations of radiation, ultrasound, hyperthermia, and photodynamic therapy as physical strategies for EPR-adaptive delivery to EPR-insensitive tumor phenotypes, and we reflect upon changes in the preclinical research pathway that should be implemented in order to optimally validate and develop these delivery strategies.

paper.title: Improving accessibility of EPR-insensitive tumor phenotypes using EPR-adaptive strategies: Designing a new perspective in nanomedicine delivery

sections.title: Mechanism of the EPR Effect in Solid Tumors
sections.tldr: The EPR effect occurs due to structural abnormalities in tumor vasculature that develop during rapid tumor growth and angiogenesis, creating leaky blood vessels with gaps of 100-800 nm that allow nanoparticles to extravasate into tumor tissue. Concurrently, the dysfunctional lymphatic drainage in tumors prevents clearance of these nanoparticles, leading to their accumulation and retention in the tumor microenvironment. (10 sources)
sections.text:
The enhanced permeability and retention effect operates through a two-part mechanism that exploits the pathophysiological characteristics of solid tumors. As tumors grow rapidly, they become oxygen-deprived, triggering the secretion of growth factors that promote angiogenesis—the formation of new blood vessels from existing capillaries <Paper corpusId="139887804" paperTitle="(Porfire et al., 2017)" isShortName></Paper>. Unlike normal vasculature, these hastily formed tumor blood vessels develop with significant structural abnormalities, including discontinuous epithelium, fenestrated endothelial tubes, and lack of proper basement membranes <Paper corpusId="139887804" paperTitle="(Porfire et al., 2017)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="233458231" paperTitle="(Omabe et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>.

The irregular architecture of tumor vasculature creates gaps between endothelial cells, allowing macromolecules and nanoparticles to extravasate through these openings. While normal endothelial tight junctions prevent particles larger than 2-10 nm from passing, tumor vessel pores typically range from 100 to 780 nm in diameter, with a mean of approximately 400 nm <Paper corpusId="210823734" paperTitle="(Li et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="252393116" paperTitle="(Bozzer et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper>. This enhanced permeability enables nanoparticles in the size range of 10-500 nm to leak from the bloodstream into the tumor interstitial space <Paper corpusId="210823734" paperTitle="(Li et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="257799789" paperTitle="(Sivadasan et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper>.

The second critical component of the EPR effect is enhanced retention, which occurs due to the dysfunctional lymphatic system in tumor tissues. While molecules smaller than 4 nm can diffuse back into the bloodstream, larger nanoparticles remain trapped in the tumor interstitium due to impaired lymphatic drainage <Paper corpusId="231768481" paperTitle="(Isa et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>. This inability to efficiently clear macromolecules leads to their progressive accumulation within the tumor microenvironment <Paper corpusId="139887804" paperTitle="(Porfire et al., 2017)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="214702651" paperTitle="(Mohamed et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper>.

Several factors influence the strength of the EPR effect. At the vascular level, key contributors include vascular permeability, expression of endothelial receptors, and the degree of vascular maturation. Microenvironmental factors include the composition of the extracellular matrix, presence of hypoxia, interstitial fluid pressure, and tumor cell density <Paper corpusId="208331092" paperTitle="(Dammes et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper>. Additionally, nanoparticle characteristics such as size, shape, surface properties, porosity, and structure can modify the EPR effect <Paper corpusId="203640698" paperTitle="(Lungu et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper>.

The EPR effect facilitates nanoparticle distribution through three interconnected mechanisms: extravasation from blood vessels, diffusion into cancer tissue, and interaction with intracellular or extracellular targets within the tumor microenvironment <Paper corpusId="257799789" paperTitle="(Sivadasan et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="26005277" paperTitle="(Sun et al., 2014)" isShortName></Paper>. Generally, compounds greater than 40 kDa benefit from the EPR effect and can accumulate at tumor sites, with the added benefit of prolonged circulation time compared to smaller molecules that are rapidly cleared by the liver and kidneys <Paper corpusId="208331092" paperTitle="(Dammes et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper>.

snippets:
The underlying mechanism, which makes passive targeting possible, is the enhanced permeability and retention (EPR) effect. 

It was observed that certain circumstances, such as inflammation/hypoxia, tumors, or infarcts, can determine an enhanced permeability of the endothelial lining of the blood vessel wall compared with the normal state of the tissue (Shaji et al., 2013). When reaching a given size, a tumor can no longer rely on the normal vasculature present in its vicinity to provide all the oxygen supply needed for its further proliferation. Therefore, as oxygen-deprived cells start to die, they secrete growth factors that promote the formation of new blood vessels from the surrounding capillaries, process known as angiogenesis (Bertrand et al., 2014). These newly formed irregular blood vessels lack the basal membrane of normal vascular structures, thus presenting a discontinuous epithelium, which allows particles, such as nanocarriers (in the size range of 20-200 nm), to extravasate and accumulate inside the interstitial space (Jain et al., 2010). Following permeation into the tumor, the enhanced accumulation of nanocarriers in the tumor microenvironment is favored by the poor lymphatic drainage in the tissue. In tumors, the lymphatic function is defective, resulting in minimal uptake of the interstitial fluid. Therefore, nanocarriers that have reached the perivascular space are not cleared efficiently and accumulate in the tumor interstitium (Bertrand et al., 2014).

paper.title: Liposomal Nanoformulations as Current Tumor-Targeting Approach to Cancer Therapy

snippets: Tumor cells, in a frantic attempt to mitigate the circumstance of limited diffusion, which negatively influences nutrient supply, oxygen supply and waste removal, engage in neoangiogenesis to step up vasculature. In order to avoid the imminent consequences of hypoxia, ischemia and toxicity, this process seems to occur very quickly and as a result, the contributions of the angiogenic regulators are largely excluded. This gives rise to highly disorganized and fenestrated tumor vessels, with discontinued endothelial linings and undesirable permeability to particles of up to 700 nm in diameter (Moghimi et al., 2018)(Fang et al., 2011). This pathologically orchestrated phenomenon is referred to as enhanced permeability and retention (EPR) effect (Matsumura et al., 1986) (Figure 2). Maeda et al. conceptualized and clearly demonstrated how angiogenic flaws associated with rapid tumor growth promoted site-specific accumulation and retention of nanoparticle-drug conjugates at the tumor site (Matsumura et al., 1986)(Maeda, 2012). Taking advantage of the pressure gradient and leaky vessels at the tumor site, the nanoparticle-based drug accumulates at the tumor site, extravasates into the tumor microenvironment, and prolongs the release of therapeutic agents within the tumor with a resultant improvement in the treatment outcome.

paper.title: Nanovectorization of Prostate Cancer Treatment Strategies: A New Approach to Improved Outcomes

snippets: The nanoparticles enter the tumor matrix through the defected microvascular endothelium around the tumor, and are retained due to blockage of lymphatic vessel reflux. This basic principle of enhanced permeability and retention (EPR) effects to achieve passive targeting of nanoparticles to solid tumors. Because of the tight junctions in the normal endothelial cell gap, it prevents particles larger than 2 nm from passing. However, the tight junctions of the tumor vasculature and the basement membrane are disordered, allowing 10 to 500 nm NP to exude and accumulate in tumor matrix (Bertrand et al., 2014). The lymphatic system of the tumor is also damaged; further intercepting macromolecular particles and delaying their outflow (Maeda et al., 2013). So, the EPR effect allows tumors to retain more polymer NPs, proteins, liposomes and micelles than other tissues (Kamaly et al., 2012).

paper.title: Nanocarrier-mediated antioxidant delivery for liver diseases

snippets: Solid tumors are characterized by a heterogeneous vasculature for size and distribution, constituted by a central avascular/necrotic region and a vascularized peripheral region, with discontinuous endothelium in the micro-vessels. In fact, depending on the anatomic region of a tumor, the pore size of the endothelial junctions varies from 100 to 780 nm with a mean of approximately 400 nm (while normal vasculature is characterized by pores smaller than 10 nm), characterizing the leaky microvasculature of tumors; it is also characterized by a disrupted basement membrane, abnormal branching, and enlarged inter-endothelial gaps, with an associated breakdown of tight junctions between endothelial cells. Moreover, tumor vasculature lacks lymphatic drainage and is rich in fenestrations and poor in pericyte coverage. All these features contribute to the enhanced permeability and retention (EPR) effect, firstly described by Maeda and co-workers (Maeda et al., 2013); the tumor vasculature architecture allows extravasation and selective accumulation of nanodrugs in the tumor interstice via a passive targeting mechanism (Sanna et al., 2014)(Bertrand et al., 2014)(Aghebati-Maleki et al., 2019).

paper.title: Nanocarriers as a Delivery Platform for Anticancer Treatment: Biological Limits and Perspectives in B-Cell Malignancies

snippets: The enhanced permeability and retention effect allows tumor targeting due to the tumor microenvironment characteristics.In normal conditions, nanoparticle extravasation does not occur; however, the discontinuity of the vascular epithelium in the tumor region and the improper functioning of the lymphatic drainage system facilitate enhanced extravasation.Angiogenesis stimulates the formation of irregular blood vessels with discontinuous epithelium in tumor sites.The increased permeability is due to the discontinuities between epithelial cells, nanoparticles in the size range from 100 to 800 nm can flow across the interstitial space.Tumor tissues have a dysfunctional lymphatic system and insufficient lymphatic outflow, resulting in nanoparticle accumulation in the tumor tissue.The EPR effect influences molecular distribution through three related mechanisms: nanoparticle extravasation from blood arteries, nanoparticle diffusion into cancer tissue, and nanoparticle interaction with intracellular or extracellular targets in the tumor microenvironment (Sun et al., 2014)(Costa et al., 2019).

paper.title: Solid Lipid Nanoparticles: Applications and Prospects in Cancer Treatment

snippets: Solid tumors grow at a rapid rate, and this comes with high nutrients and oxygen demand. Thus, new blood vessels and neovasculature were formed, and this is term as angiogenesis. These new blood vessels often exhibit disorganized course, irregular, discontinuous epithelium and structurally different from healthy vessels. Due to this, the nanoparticles can leak between the gaps and enter the tumor. This stage is referring to the enhanced permeability of the EPR effect. It should be noted that solid tumor has poor lymphatic drainage. Molecules smaller than 4 nm can diffuse back to the bloodstream, but the nanoparticles are impeded due to their larger particle size, thus retain in the solid tumor. This part refers to the retention of the EPR effect (Narum et al., 2019)[129].

paper.title: Progress in Mesoporous Silica Nanoparticles as Drug Delivery Agents for Cancer Treatment

snippets: Neovascularization is essential for tumor progression, to ensure an adequate supply of oxygen and nutrients which support their growth. The imbalance of angiogenic regulators create an abnormal vascular network of tumor tissue that is highly disorganized and characterized by dilated, leaky blood vessels and exhibiting poor lymphatic drainage (Nakamura et al., 2014). Such unique pathophysiologic properties of tumor vasculature provide nanosized drug carriers with long circulation time. For example, PEGylated liposomes were leaked and retained specifically into tumor tissues rather than normal ones. Consequently, reduced drug toxicity is expected when using PEGylated liposomes containing anticancer drugs. This process is known as enhanced permeability and retention effect (EPR) and is extensively exploited to achieve passive targeting of chemotherapeutic agents (Nakamura et al., 2014)(Andriyanov et al., 2017)(Buyens et al., 2012). EPR was described for the first time by Maeda and co-workers (Blanco et al., 2015). Also, it is demonstrated that EPR effect is the major mechanism for the selective accumulation of nanotherapeutics in tumors (La‐Beck et al., 2017)

On the other hand, tumor properties like tumor size, type of cancer and extent of tumor vasculature have a great effect on the extent of extravasation and tumor accumulation of PEGylated liposomes [45].

paper.title: Liposomes and PEGylated liposomes as drug delivery system

snippets: Due to the rapid growth of tumors, the surrounding blood vessels have a defective architecture and in some cases produce various permeability factors to ensure sufficient influx of oxygen and nutrients [89]. This feature is exploited in cancer therapy to enhance tumor accumulation of macromolecules. The molecules first pass the endothelial barrier followed by movement through the tumor interstitium and extracellular matrix before they reach the tumor cells. Generally, compounds greater than 40 kDa benefit from the EPR effect and can accumulate at the tumor site. An additional benefit of these macromolecules is their prolonged circulation time compared to smaller molecules that are rapidly cleared by the liver and kidneys [49]. While targeted molecules have tumor targeting abilities, their initial diffusion from the vasculature into the tumor tissue relies on the EPR effect like untargeted molecules. Due to the inter-and intra-patient heterogeneity of the EPR effect, treatment efficacy varies between patients, leading to dissimilar outcomes in clinical trials. The EPR effect is so heterologous because multiple vascular as well as micro-environmental factors contribute to the EPR. At the vascular level, main contributors are vascular permeability, expression of endothelial receptors and the degree of vascular maturation (as tumors rapidly enhance angiogenesis the maturation state is significantly different from healthy tissues). Micro-environmental contributors include the extracellular matrix, presence of hypoxia, interstitial fluid pressure and tumor cell density [90]. When taking into account all these different contributors, one can imagine the complexity and understand the heterogeneous nature. Because of this EPR heterogeneity, antibodies provide an opportunity for active targeting that can enhance the passive targeting of the EPR effect.

paper.title: Monoclonal antibody-based molecular imaging strategies and theranostic opportunities

snippets: These nanoparticles agglomerate in the cancerous site as a consequence of the enhanced permeability and retention effect (EPR), which has been known to be a result of poor vasculature in the tumor site. However, although it sounds somewhat simplistic at first, EPR is a very complex process that can be influenced by several biological actions made by the systematic distribution of nanoparticles. Interactions between proteins and nanoparticles, blood flow, and the tumor microenvironment are all factors that can influence EPR. The EPR effect can also be manipulated by the nanoparticles' features, such as their dimensions, shape, surface properties, porosity, and structure (Shi et al., 2016).

paper.title: Nanobiomaterials Used in Cancer Therapy: An Up-To-Date Overview

snippets: In medicine, nanotechnology has sparked a rapidly growing interest as it promises to solve a number of issues associated with conventional therapeutic agents, including their poor water solubility (at least, for most anticancer drugs), lack of targeting capability, nonspecific distribution, systemic toxicity, and low therapeutic index. Over the past several decades, remarkable progress has been made in the development and application of engineered nanoparticles to treat cancer more effectively. For example, therapeutic agents have been integrated with nanoparticles engineered with optimal sizes, shapes, and surface properties to increase their solubility, prolong their circulation half-life, improve their biodistribution, and reduce their immunogenicity. Nanoparticles and their payloads have also been favorably delivered into tumors by taking advantage of the pathophysiological conditions, such as the enhanced permeability and retention effect, and the spatial variations in the pH value. Additionally, targeting ligands (e.g., small organic molecules, peptides, antibodies, and nucleic acids) have been added to the surface of nanoparticles to specifically target cancerous cells through selective binding to the receptors overexpressed on their surface. Furthermore, it has been demonstrated that multiple types of therapeutic drugs and/or diagnostic agents (e.g., contrast agents) could be delivered through the same carrier to enable combination therapy with a potential to overcome multidrug resistance, and real-time readout on the treatment efficacy. It is anticipated that precisely engineered nanoparticles will emerge as the next-generation platform for cancer therapy and many other biomedical applications.

paper.title: Engineered nanoparticles for drug delivery in cancer therapy.

sections.title: EPR Effect in Malignant Solid Tumors and Tumor Vasculature
sections.tldr: The EPR effect is particularly pronounced in malignant solid tumors due to their abnormal vasculature characterized by large fenestrations (100-800 nm), discontinuous epithelium, and defective lymphatic drainage, allowing nanoparticles to selectively accumulate in tumor tissues. However, the EPR effect varies significantly across tumor types, stages, and locations, with some tumors like pancreatic cancer showing limited EPR-based accumulation due to dense extracellular matrix. (9 sources)
sections.text:
Solid tumors exhibit unique pathophysiological characteristics that facilitate the EPR effect, including angiogenesis, rapid growth, and metastasis. The enhanced permeability of tumor blood vessels is not merely a side effect but actually a prerequisite for rapid tumor growth, as it allows tumors to meet their substantial demands for nutrients and oxygen <Paper corpusId="13707720" paperTitle="(Wu et al., 2001)" isShortName></Paper>. This enhanced permeability stems from the abnormal development of tumor vasculature, which grows rapidly to support the expanding tumor mass.

The vasculature in malignant tumors is structurally distinct from normal blood vessels. Tumor blood vessels are characterized by excessive leakiness with large fenestrations measuring 100-800 nm in diameter <Paper corpusId="231776619" paperTitle="(Gagliardi et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>. Additionally, these vessels exhibit discontinuous epithelium, increased tortuosity, pericyte deficiency, and atypical membrane formation <Paper corpusId="237459096" paperTitle="(Sedush et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>. The aberrant branching and large openings between endothelial cells are consequences of rapid proliferation and decreased pericyte coverage <Paper corpusId="267086100" paperTitle="(Garcia-Dominguez et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>. These structural abnormalities allow macromolecules and nanoparticles to more easily penetrate tumor tissues than normal tissues, where the vasculature remains intact and less permeable <Paper corpusId="55688965" paperTitle="(Babu et al., 2013)" isShortName></Paper>.

Several molecular mechanisms contribute to the hyperpermeability of tumor blood vessels. Tumors secrete various factors such as nitric oxide, prostaglandins, bradykinin, and fibroblast growth factors. Additionally, they overexpress genes related to vascular permeability factor and vascular endothelial growth factor, all of which promote the hyperpermeability of tumor microvessels <Paper corpusId="237459096" paperTitle="(Sedush et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>. This enhanced vascular permeability, coupled with dysfunctional lymphatic drainage, creates an environment where nanoparticles can accumulate at levels 10-200 times higher than in normal tissues <Paper corpusId="227260630" paperTitle="(Fu et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper>.

While the EPR effect provides a foundation for passive targeting of nanomedicines to solid tumors, it is important to recognize that its effectiveness varies considerably across different tumor types. For instance, hypovascular tumors such as prostate or pancreatic cancers show limited EPR-based accumulation <Paper corpusId="231776619" paperTitle="(Gagliardi et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>. Pancreatic ductal carcinoma, in particular, is characterized by a very dense extracellular matrix that restricts the EPR effect <Paper corpusId="226219426" paperTitle="(Gaspar et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper>. Analysis of 200 different patient tumors across eight cancer types revealed marked differences in tumor vasculature and morphology not only between tumor types but also between tumors of the same type and even within individual tumors <Paper corpusId="226219426" paperTitle="(Gaspar et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper>.

Furthermore, the EPR effect depends on the stage of tumor development. Very early-stage tumors, small metastasized cancers, and blood cancers typically exhibit insignificant or no EPR effect <Paper corpusId="227260630" paperTitle="(Fu et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper>. Early-stage tumors often have more regular vasculature that prevents effective passive targeting <Paper corpusId="235383131" paperTitle="(Gunaydin et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>. Additionally, vascular permeability changes as tumors progress and varies depending on the tumor's anatomical location <Paper corpusId="237459096" paperTitle="(Sedush et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>.

In solid tumors such as lung cancer, the presence of highly fenestrated blood vessels facilitates the enhanced entry of colloidal nanoparticles, while the poor lymphatic flow contributes to their retention within the tumor site <Paper corpusId="55688965" paperTitle="(Babu et al., 2013)" isShortName></Paper>. The high vascular density resulting from angiogenesis in solid tumors, combined with the large gaps between endothelial cells, enables selective extravasation and retention of macromolecular drugs <Paper corpusId="62886804" paperTitle="(Gajbhiye et al., 2017)" isShortName></Paper>.

snippets: Solid tumors exhibit unique pathophysiological characteristics such as angiogenesis, rapid growth, and metastasis. Enhanced permeability of tumor vasculature allows tumor tissue to meet the great demand for nutrients and oxygen. Such enhanced permeability is thus a prerequisite for rapid tumor growth. We previously demonstrated that solid tumors have a unique characteristic of enhanced vascular permeability and retention of macromolecular and lipidic agents, which we termed the enhanced permeability and retention effect (EPR effect).

paper.title: Enhanced Vascular Permeability in Solid Tumor Involving Peroxynitrite and Matrix Metalloproteinases
paper.venue: Japanese journal of cancer research : Gann

snippets: Passive targeting (Figure 5) exploits the peculiar anatomical and pathological abnormalities of the tumor vasculature which promote the accumulation of polymeric nanoparticles in the perivascular tumor region by convection or passive diffusion (Bazak et al., 2014)

The excessive leakiness of tumor vasculature, characterized by large fenestrations with a mean diameter of 100-800 nm, promotes the localization of nanoparticles into the interstitial space as a consequence of the "enhanced permeability" effect. At the same time, inefficient drainage of the tumor tissue due to the absence or ineffectiveness of lymphatic vessels results in "enhanced retention" of nanoparticles. Together, these two phenomena are known as the "Enhanced Permeability and Retention" (EPR) effect. The EPR effect is the cornerstone in nanoparticle-mediated drug delivery in cancers, especially in solid tumors which are characterized by rapid growth, with the exception of hypovascular tumors such as prostate or pancreatic cancer (Danhier et al., 2012).

paper.title: Biodegradable Polymeric Nanoparticles for Drug Delivery to Solid Tumors

snippets: Passive targeting to solid tumors can be achieved through the enhanced permeability and retention effect (EPR effect), as first described in the 1980s [13,14]. Pathological, pharmacological, and biochemical studies have shown that a solid tumor usually has such pathophysiological characteristics as hypervascularization, incomplete vascular architecture, and secretion of vascular permeability factors that stimulate extravasation and immaturity of lymphatic capillaries [15]. The tumor vasculature is characterized by a high proportion of proliferating endothelial cells, increased tortuosity, pericyte deficiency, and the formation of an atypical membrane. All this leads to rapid vascularization of the tumor, which is necessary to provide it with oxygen and nutrients and further proliferation. These characteristics make tumor blood vessels permeable to macromolecules. In addition, the lymphatic drainage system of the tumor functions ineffectively due to immature lymphatic capillaries; thus, nanocarriers are selectively preserved for a long period in the interstitial tissue of the tumor [15]. Numerous studies have shown that the EPR effect induces passive accumulation of macromolecules and micelles in solid tumors, enhancing the therapeutic effect while reducing side effects. It was also found that in most human tumors the effective pore size in the vasculature ranges from 200 to 600 nm in diameter, which allows passive targeting of tumors [16]. It was noted that the secretion of various factors such as nitric oxide, prostaglandins, bradykinin, and the main growth factor of fibroblasts in tumor tissues and overexpression of genes (such as vascular permeability factor or vascular endothelial growth factor) cause hyperpermeability of tumor microvessels. However, let us note that vascular permeability in the tumor changes with its progression and depends on the type of tumor and its anatomical location.

paper.title: Nanoformulations of Drugs Based on Biodegradable Lactide Copolymers with Various Molecular Structures and Architectures

snippets: The main mechanism of tumor targeting of anticancer nanomedicines is based on the Enhanced Permeability and Retention (EPR) effect, first described by Matsumura and Maeda in 1986 (Matsumura et al., 1986) as a passive yet powerful targeting strategy. They showed that tumor tissues had defective blood vessels with aberrant branching and large openings between endothelial cells of around 400 nm due to their rapid proliferation and decreased number of pericytes. This unique characteristic helps macromolecules, such as nanocarriers, easily move into tumor tissues after crossing the endothelium barrier. Furthermore, solid tumors have a poor lymphatic drainage system, leading to extended retention times of nanocarriers in the tumor extracellular matrix.

paper.title: Cancer Nano-Immunotherapy: The Novel and Promising Weapon to Fight Cancer

snippets: In solid tumors, such as lung cancer, the EPR effect plays an important role in determining the efficacy of the nanoparticle-based drug delivery system (Maeda, 2001). The presence of a highly fenestrated blood vasculature in the tumor facilitates the EPR effect allowing the enhanced entry of colloidal nanoparticles into the tumor (Figure 2). Additionally, the poor lymphatic flow in the tumor tissue adds to this effect and results in enhanced retention of nanoparticles within the tumor site. In contrast to tumor tissues, the blood vasculature in normal tissues is intact and less permeable attenuating the uptake of nanoparticles by normal tissues.

paper.title: Nanoparticle-based drug delivery for therapy of lung cancer: progress and challenges

snippets: Passive targeting of nanoparticles refers to the passive accumulation of nanoparticles in the tumor tissue, which is generally attributed to the enhanced permeability and retention effect.The concept of EPR was first introduced more than 30 years ago when Maeda and colleagues found that certain macromolecules accumulate preferentially in the tumor tissue (Matsumura et al., 1986).EPR is mainly the result of leakiness of the discontinuous endothelium of angiogenic tumor vasculature combined with defective lymphatic drainage of the tumor matrix, which facilitates the extravasation and accumulation of nanoparticles in tumor.It has been shown that the number of nanoparticles accumulated in tumor tissue may be 10-200 times higher than in normal tissue as a result of EPR.The EPR effect is considered to be the primary element to improve the efficacy and safety of nanotherapeutics.In fact, most of the nanomedicines marketed thus far base their increased therapeutic index mainly on the EPR effect [5]

The EPR effect is not effective for some cancers because of tumor heterogeneity and cancer stage, is even not applicable to some types of cancers, and it is not effective in some patients because of individual differences
It is manifest that blood cancers, very early stage tumors, and small metastasized cancers do not have or have only insignificant EPR effect.

paper.title: Aptamer-Functionalized Nanoparticles in Targeted Delivery and Cancer Therapy

snippets: The Enhanced Permeability and Retention (EPR) effect is a phenomenon that leads to the enhanced accumulation and retention of macromolecules and nanoparticles in solid tumors compared to normal tissues (Bertrand et al., 2014)(Lammers et al., 2012). This improved accumulation results from the tumor vasculature that grows abnormally in order to feed the rapidly growing tumor. This results in leaks in the vasculature, from which nanomedicines can penetrate the tumor. However, the EPR effect is not a universal property of all solid tumors and care should be taken when exploring this route of passive tumor targeting (Lammers et al., 2012). Some tumors have a very dense extracellular matrix with very limited EPR-based accumulation (e.g., pancreatic ductal carcinoma). In addition, analysis from 200 different patient tumors across eight different cancer types have revealed marked differences in the tumor vasculature and morphology, observed between tumor types, between tumors of the same type, and even within the same tumor (Golombek et al., 2018)(Lammers et al., 2012).

paper.title: Lipid-Nucleic Acid Complexes: Physicochemical Aspects and Prospects for Cancer Treatment

snippets: The EPR effect is a common concept for solid tumors associated with their pathophysiological and anatomical differences from normal tissues (Matsumura et al., 1986). The EPR effect is manifested by enhanced accumulation of macromolecules (e.g. liposomes, drugs, and NPs) in tumor tissues in contrast to normal tissues. The mechanism underlying this effect is attributed to the leaky vessels around tumors as well as dysfunctional lymphatic system (Perrault et al., 2010)(Maeda, 2013). The blood vessels with such leaky pores can augment the transport of circulating nanoparticles into the tumor. On the other hand, the transportation in nonmalignant tissues is hindered by the intact barrier of the vasculature. EPR effect has been proposed to be due to the rapid growth of tumor cells, which require surplus amounts of crucial nutrients; thus, inducing the dysregulated formation of blood vasculatures
The passive targeting strategy may fail to achieve the desired favorable therapeutic effects in certain early stage tumors, because of the regular vasculature of such tissues.

paper.title: Photodynamic Therapy—Current Limitations and Novel Approaches

snippets: The enhanced permeability and retention (EPR) effect is a unique phenomenon of solid tumors related to their anatomical and pathophysiological differences from normal tissues. In solid tumors, angiogenesis leads to high vascular density. Large gaps exist between endothelial cells in tumor blood vessels, which lead to selective extravasations and retention of macromolecular drugs.

paper.title: EPR effect based nanocarriers targeting for treatment of cancer

sections.title: EPR Effect and Metastasis
sections.tldr: The EPR effect presents a paradoxical role in metastasis—while leaky tumor vasculature can facilitate the escape of cancer cells into circulation promoting metastatic spread, this same vascular permeability enables targeted nanoparticle accumulation for therapeutic intervention. Evidence suggests the EPR effect occurs in metastatic lesions, though its presence varies by stage and location, creating both challenges and opportunities for nanomedicine-based treatment of metastatic disease. (9 sources)
sections.text:
The relationship between the EPR effect and metastasis presents a complex duality in cancer progression and treatment. The enhanced permeability of tumor vasculature, which enables nanoparticle accumulation for therapeutic purposes, simultaneously creates pathways for cancer cells to escape the primary tumor and enter circulation. This leaky vasculature is considered a "double-edged sword"—facilitating both the accumulation of therapeutic nanoparticles at tumor sites and the dissemination of tumor cells that can establish distant metastases <Paper corpusId="247886899" paperTitle="(Milligan et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper>.

The abnormal lymphatic architecture within tumors plays a critical role in both the EPR effect and metastatic potential. While the enhanced retention component of the EPR effect results from collapsed internal lymphatic vessels due to high tissue pressure, metastatic spread often occurs through functional lymphatic vessels at the tumor periphery <Paper corpusId="209377402" paperTitle="(Thomas et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper>. This spatial heterogeneity of lymphatic function within tumors creates a complex environment that simultaneously promotes nanoparticle retention and enables cancer cell dissemination.

Endothelial cells in tumor vasculature exhibit distinct characteristics that influence both the EPR effect and metastatic potential. Research has demonstrated that tumor endothelial cells (TECs) differ significantly from normal endothelial cells in their proliferation rates, gene expression profiles, and responses to growth factors <Paper corpusId="222172164" paperTitle="(Nii et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="16213814" paperTitle="(Amin et al., 2006)" isShortName></Paper>. Notably, endothelial cells isolated from highly metastatic tumors (HM-TECs) show higher secretion levels of vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF), matrix metalloproteinases (MMP-2, MMP-9), and stromal cell-derived factor-1 (SDF-1) compared to those from low metastatic tumors <Paper corpusId="222172164" paperTitle="(Nii et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="4308498" paperTitle="(Kurosu et al., 2011)" isShortName></Paper>. These molecular differences contribute to the hyperpermeability of vessels in metastatic tumors and potentially facilitate both the EPR effect and metastatic progression.

The presence of the EPR effect in metastatic lesions remains a subject of ongoing investigation, with somewhat conflicting findings. Some studies report that the EPR effect occurs not only in primary tumors but also in metastatic sites, including lymphatic, liver, and lung metastases <Paper corpusId="255059944" paperTitle="(Islam et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper>. However, other research suggests that the EPR effect may not be universal in metastatic disease, particularly in early-stage metastases <Paper corpusId="53104302" paperTitle="(Adjei et al., 2018)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="13578458" paperTitle="(Mikada et al., 2017)" isShortName></Paper>. For instance, in a study of lymph node metastasis, the EPR effect was not detected until day 29 post-inoculation, suggesting that systemic nanoparticle-based chemotherapy might not be effective during early metastatic stages <Paper corpusId="13578458" paperTitle="(Mikada et al., 2017)" isShortName></Paper>.

The heterogeneity of the EPR effect across different tumor types and stages has significant implications for the treatment of metastatic disease <Paper corpusId="53104302" paperTitle="(Adjei et al., 2018)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="4784007" paperTitle="(Hansen et al., 2015)" isShortName></Paper>. As metastatic lesions develop and establish their own vasculature, they may exhibit varying degrees of vascular permeability and lymphatic dysfunction, resulting in different levels of nanoparticle accumulation. This heterogeneity presents both challenges and opportunities for the development of nanomedicine-based approaches to target metastatic disease, suggesting that EPR-independent drug delivery systems may be necessary for treating early-stage metastases when the EPR effect is not yet established.

snippets: It is this enhanced permeability that is a double-edged sword for cancer: on the one hand, it is believed to enhance tumor metastasis by allowing the escape of tumor cells into the infiltrating vessels, which circulate them across the body to distant metastatic sites (Iyer et al., 2006); on the other hand, the leaky vasculature unique to the tumor microenvironment promotes the accumulation of systemically circulating nanoparticles at the tumor site, a phenomenon that should enhance the therapeutic efficacy of nanoparticle drugs against solid tumors.

paper.title: A Nanoparticle’s Journey to the Tumor: Strategies to Overcome First-Pass Metabolism and Their Limitations

snippets: The second component, the enhanced retention, is a consequence of the aberrant lymphatic architecture (Stacker et al., 2014). Although metastatic spread frequently occurs by means of lymphatic dissemination, this appears to be mediated by lymphatic vessels in the periphery of the tumor mass, whereas internal vessels tend to collapse under the high tissue pressure (Leu et al., 2000)(Padera et al., 2002).

paper.title: Overcoming Physiological Barriers to Nanoparticle Delivery—Are We There Yet?

snippets: Enhanced permeation and retention effect (EPR effect) is a concept to symbolize this condition of cancer blood vessels (Hida et al., 2013). Based on the EPR effect concept, a positive targeting of micelles containing anticancer drug to cancer has been reported (Cabral et al., 2014)(Matsumura et al., 2009). Thus, there are some structural and functional differences between the cancer and normal blood vessels. To study cancer characteristics or therapeutic efficacy, the blood vessel properties and the cancer-endothelial cell interaction are important to consider. Some research has been reported to demonstrate that tumor endothelial cells (TEC) differ from normal endothelial cells in properties, such as the cell proliferation, the gene expression, the response to growth factors, or migration (Akino et al., 2009)(Amin et al., 2006). High metastatic tumor-derived TEC (HM-TEC) and low metastatic tumor-derived TEC (LM-TEC) can be isolated from mice. It is demonstrated that the secretion levels of VEGF, MMP-2, MMP-9, and SDF-1 from HM-TEC are higher than from that of LM-TEC (Hida et al., 2013)(Kurosu et al., 2011).

paper.title: Three-Dimensional Culture System of Cancer Cells Combined with Biomaterials for Drug Screening

snippets: Epidermal growth factor (EGF) receptor family members are expressed by tumor cells and contribute to tumor progression. The expression and activity of EGF receptors in endothelial cells are less well characterized. Analysis of tumor-derived endothelial cells showed that they express EGFR, ErbB2, and ErbB4, whereas their normal counterparts express ErbB2, ErbB3, and ErbB4. The gain in expression of EGFR and the loss of ErbB3 expression in tumor vasculature was also observed in vivo. As a consequence of their expressing EGFR, tumor endothelial cells responded to EGF and other EGF family members by activating both EGFR and ErbB2, by activating the downstream mitogen-activated protein kinase pathway, and by enhanced proliferation. On the other hand, normal endothelial cells did not respond to EGF but instead were responsive to neuregulin (NRG), a ligand for ErbB3 and ErbB4. NRG activated ErbB3 in normal endothelial cells and inhibited growth of these cells. In contrast, tumor endothelial cells, which do not express ErbB3, were not growth inhibited by NRG. Furthermore, due to their expression of EGFR, tumor endothelial cells, unlike normal endothelial cells, are direct targets for EGFR kinase inhibitors. These low-molecular-weight compounds block EGF-induced EGFR activation and proliferation of tumor endothelial cells. These results suggest that a gain of EGF-induced endothelial cell proliferation, and loss of NRG-induced growth inhibition in tumor endothelial cells constitutes a switch that promotes tumor angiogenesis. In addition, these results suggest that EGFR kinase inhibitors may be effective for antiangiogenesis therapy by specifically targeting the tumor, but not the normal, vasculature.

paper.title: Tumor endothelial cells express epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) but not ErbB3 and are responsive to EGF and to EGFR kinase inhibitors.

snippets: Background:Tumour stromal cells differ from its normal counterpart. We have shown that tumour endothelial cells (TECs) isolated from tumour tissues are also abnormal. Furthermore, we found that mRNAs of vascular endothelial growth factor-A (VEGF-A) and cyclooxygenase-2 (COX-2) were upregulated in TECs. Vascular endothelial growth factor-A and COX-2 are angiogenic factors and their mRNAs contain an AU-rich element (ARE). AU-rich element-containing mRNAs are reportedly stabilised by Hu antigen R (HuR), which is exported to the cytoplasm.Methods:Normal endothelial cell (NEC) and two types of TECs were isolated. We evaluated the correlation of HuR and accumulation of VEGF-A and COX-2 mRNAs in TECs and effects of HuR on biological phenotypes of TECs.Results:The HuR protein was accumulated in the cytoplasm of TECs, but not in NECs. Vascular endothelial growth factor-A and COX-2 mRNA levels decreased due to HuR knockdown and it was shown that these ARE-mRNA were bound to HuR in TECs. Furthermore, HuR knockdown inhibited cell survival, random motility, tube formation, and Akt phosphorylation in TECs.Conclusion:Hu antigen R is associated with the upregulation of VEGF-A and COX-2 mRNA in TECs, and has an important role in keeping an angiogenic switch on, through activating angiogenic phenotype in tumour endothelium.

paper.title: HuR keeps an angiogenic switch on by stabilising mRNA of VEGF and COX-2 in tumour endothelium

snippets: The EPR effect occurs not only in primary cancers but also in metastatic cancers including lymphatic, liver, and lung metastases and in inflamed tissues (Maeda, 2015)(Fang et al., 2020)[11](Daruwalla et al., 2008).

paper.title: Enhanced Permeability and Retention Effect as a Ubiquitous and Epoch-Making Phenomenon for the Selective Drug Targeting of Solid Tumors

snippets: The effectiveness of NPs is dependent on their accumulation in vascularized solid tumors via the enhanced permeability and retention (EPR) effect. Fast-growing tumors develop poorly organized vasculature with large endothelial fenestrations that allows NPs to accumulate in the tumor interstitium. Tumors also have impaired lymphatic drainage that enhances NP retention in the tumor (Fang et al., 2011)(Nichols et al., 2014). Although the EPR effect has served as the foundation for most cancer nanomedicines, there is heterogeneity in its presentation based on tumor type and patient population. Furthermore, the size of a tumor and the heterogeneous tumor microenvironment affect the EPR effect (Hansen et al., 2015). The existence of the EPR effect in metastasis is an unresolved question, with studies reporting that metastases exhibit the phenomenon (Maeda, 2015), while others report otherwise, especially in early-stage metastasis (Mikada et al., 2017).

paper.title: Targeted Nanomedicine to Treat Bone Metastasis

snippets: Most solid cancers spread to new sites via the lymphatics before hematogenous dissemination. However, only a small fraction of an intravenously administered anti‐cancer drug enters the lymphatic system to reach metastatic lymph nodes (LN). Here, we show that the enhanced permeability and retention (EPR) effect is not induced during the early stages of LN metastasis. Luciferase‐expressing tumor cells were injected into the subiliac LN of the MXH10/Mo‐lpr/lpr mouse to induce metastasis to the proper axillary LN (PALN). In vivo biofluorescence imaging was used to confirm metastasis induction and to quantify the EPR effect, measured as PALN accumulation of intravenously injected indocyanine green (ICG) liposomes. PALN blood vessel volume changes were measured by contrast‐enhanced high‐frequency ultrasound imaging. The volume and density of blood vessels in the PALN increased until day 29 after inoculation, whereas the LN volume remained constant. ICG retention was first detected on day 29 post‐inoculation. While CD31‐positive cells increased up to day 29 post‐inoculation, α‐smooth muscle actin‐positive cells were detected on day 29 post‐inoculation for the first time. These results suggest that the EPR effect was not induced in the early stages of LN metastasis; therefore, systemic chemotherapy would likely not be beneficial during the early stages of LN metastasis. The development of an alternative drug delivery system, independent of the EPR effect, is required for the treatment of LN metastasis.

paper.title: Evaluation of the enhanced permeability and retention effect in the early stages of lymph node metastasis

snippets: Since the first report of the enhanced permeability and retention (EPR) effect, the research in nanocarrier based antitumor drugs has been intense. The field has been devoted to treatment of cancer by exploiting EPR-based accumulation of nanocarriers in solid tumors, which for many years was considered to be a ubiquitous phenomenon. However, the understanding of differences in the EPR-effect between tumor types, heterogeneities within each patient group, and dependency on tumor development stage in humans is sparse. It is therefore important to enhance our understanding of the EPR-effect in large animals and humans with spontaneously developed cancer. In the present paper, we describe a novel loading method of copper-64 into PEGylated liposomes and use these liposomes to evaluate the EPR-effect in 11 canine cancer patients with spontaneous solid tumors by PET/CT imaging. We thereby provide the first high-resolution analysis of EPR-based tumor accumulation in large animals. We find that the EPR-effect is strong in some tumor types but cannot be considered a general feature of solid malignant tumors since we observed a high degree of accumulation heterogeneity between tumors. Six of seven included carcinomas displayed high uptake levels of liposomes, whereas one of four sarcomas displayed signs of liposome retention. We conclude that nanocarrier-radiotracers could be important in identifying cancer patients that will benefit from nanocarrier-based therapeutics in clinical practice.

paper.title: Positron Emission Tomography Based Elucidation of the Enhanced Permeability and Retention Effect in Dogs with Cancer Using Copper-64 Liposomes.

sections.title: Heterogeneity and Limitations of the EPR Effect
sections.tldr: While the EPR effect enables passive targeting of nanomedicines to tumors, its effectiveness varies dramatically across tumor types, locations, and individual patients due to tumor-specific characteristics and vascular architecture. These limitations challenge the universal application of EPR-based drug delivery strategies, with some tumors showing minimal or no EPR effect due to factors like dense extracellular matrix, tumor stage, or specific phenotypic characteristics. (12 sources)
sections.text:
Despite its fundamental role in nanomedicine development, the EPR effect exhibits significant heterogeneity that limits its universal application across all cancers. This heterogeneity exists between different tumor types, between tumors of the same type, and even within individual tumors <Paper corpusId="226219426" paperTitle="(Gaspar et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper>. Analysis of 200 different patient tumors across eight cancer types revealed marked differences in tumor vasculature and morphology, highlighting the variable nature of the EPR effect <Paper corpusId="226219426" paperTitle="(Gaspar et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper>. These variations stem from multiple factors operating at both vascular and microenvironmental levels.

At the vascular level, key contributors to EPR heterogeneity include differences in vascular permeability, expression of endothelial receptors, and varying degrees of vascular maturation. Microenvironmental factors further complicating the EPR effect include extracellular matrix composition, presence of hypoxia, interstitial fluid pressure, and tumor cell density <Paper corpusId="208331092" paperTitle="(Dammes et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper>. This complex interplay of factors results in unpredictable drug accumulation patterns and variable treatment outcomes between patients.

The EPR effect is notably absent or insignificant in several important clinical scenarios. Blood cancers, very early-stage tumors, and small metastasized cancers typically exhibit minimal or no EPR effect <Paper corpusId="227260630" paperTitle="(Fu et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper>. Early-stage tumors often have more organized vasculature that lacks the leakiness characteristic of more advanced tumors, limiting passive targeting opportunities <Paper corpusId="53104302" paperTitle="(Adjei et al., 2018)" isShortName></Paper>. Additionally, the EPR effect in metastatic lesions remains controversial, with some studies reporting its presence in metastases while others indicate its absence, particularly in early-stage metastatic disease <Paper corpusId="53104302" paperTitle="(Adjei et al., 2018)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="13578458" paperTitle="(Mikada et al., 2017)" isShortName></Paper>.

Certain tumor types present significant barriers to EPR-based drug delivery due to their specific structural characteristics. Pancreatic ductal carcinoma, for example, is characterized by a very dense extracellular matrix that severely restricts nanoparticle penetration and accumulation <Paper corpusId="226219426" paperTitle="(Gaspar et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper>. This limitation highlights how tumor-specific barriers can override the potential benefits of leaky vasculature.

Vascular permeability in tumors changes as they progress and varies depending on anatomical location <Paper corpusId="237459096" paperTitle="(Sedush et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="265650171" paperTitle="(Chalodiya et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper>. The size and heterogeneous microenvironment of tumors further influence the EPR effect <Paper corpusId="53104302" paperTitle="(Adjei et al., 2018)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="4784007" paperTitle="(Hansen et al., 2015)" isShortName></Paper>. In addition, while the tumor vasculature may be hyperpermeable, the high density of stromal cells and matrix proteins, combined with elevated interstitial fluid pressure, creates barriers limiting drug delivery to the tumor core <Paper corpusId="267639255" paperTitle="(Haze et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>.

Research has identified specific phenotypic characteristics of EPR-insensitive tumors, including smaller endothelial fenestrations, heterogeneous pericyte coverage, more developed and branched vasculature, relatively dense extracellular matrix, and more developed immune profiles compared to EPR-sensitive tumors <Paper corpusId="232775475" paperTitle="(Kim et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="204826101" paperTitle="(Dhaliwal et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper>. These characteristics make certain tumors inherently resistant to passive targeting strategies.

Recent studies have questioned the fundamental mechanisms of the EPR effect. Work by Chan and colleagues suggests that up to 97% of nanoparticles may not enter tumors through passive paracellular transport (the traditional explanation of the EPR effect) but rather through active transcellular processes involving endothelial cells <Paper corpusId="265146916" paperTitle="(Wang et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper>. This challenges the long-held view of the EPR effect as simply a passive phenomenon and suggests more complex mechanisms are involved in nanoparticle accumulation in tumors.

Given these significant limitations and heterogeneity, there is growing recognition that the EPR effect cannot be relied upon as the sole mechanism for tumor-targeted drug delivery across all cancer types and stages. Alternative targeting strategies that can function independently of the EPR effect, or approaches that can enhance the EPR effect in otherwise insensitive tumors, are needed to expand the clinical applicability of nanomedicine-based cancer therapies <Paper corpusId="204826101" paperTitle="(Dhaliwal et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper>.

snippets: The Enhanced Permeability and Retention (EPR) effect is a phenomenon that leads to the enhanced accumulation and retention of macromolecules and nanoparticles in solid tumors compared to normal tissues (Bertrand et al., 2014)(Lammers et al., 2012). This improved accumulation results from the tumor vasculature that grows abnormally in order to feed the rapidly growing tumor. This results in leaks in the vasculature, from which nanomedicines can penetrate the tumor. However, the EPR effect is not a universal property of all solid tumors and care should be taken when exploring this route of passive tumor targeting (Lammers et al., 2012). Some tumors have a very dense extracellular matrix with very limited EPR-based accumulation (e.g., pancreatic ductal carcinoma). In addition, analysis from 200 different patient tumors across eight different cancer types have revealed marked differences in the tumor vasculature and morphology, observed between tumor types, between tumors of the same type, and even within the same tumor (Golombek et al., 2018)(Lammers et al., 2012).

paper.title: Lipid-Nucleic Acid Complexes: Physicochemical Aspects and Prospects for Cancer Treatment

snippets: Due to the rapid growth of tumors, the surrounding blood vessels have a defective architecture and in some cases produce various permeability factors to ensure sufficient influx of oxygen and nutrients [89]. This feature is exploited in cancer therapy to enhance tumor accumulation of macromolecules. The molecules first pass the endothelial barrier followed by movement through the tumor interstitium and extracellular matrix before they reach the tumor cells. Generally, compounds greater than 40 kDa benefit from the EPR effect and can accumulate at the tumor site. An additional benefit of these macromolecules is their prolonged circulation time compared to smaller molecules that are rapidly cleared by the liver and kidneys [49]. While targeted molecules have tumor targeting abilities, their initial diffusion from the vasculature into the tumor tissue relies on the EPR effect like untargeted molecules. Due to the inter-and intra-patient heterogeneity of the EPR effect, treatment efficacy varies between patients, leading to dissimilar outcomes in clinical trials. The EPR effect is so heterologous because multiple vascular as well as micro-environmental factors contribute to the EPR. At the vascular level, main contributors are vascular permeability, expression of endothelial receptors and the degree of vascular maturation (as tumors rapidly enhance angiogenesis the maturation state is significantly different from healthy tissues). Micro-environmental contributors include the extracellular matrix, presence of hypoxia, interstitial fluid pressure and tumor cell density [90]. When taking into account all these different contributors, one can imagine the complexity and understand the heterogeneous nature. Because of this EPR heterogeneity, antibodies provide an opportunity for active targeting that can enhance the passive targeting of the EPR effect.

paper.title: Monoclonal antibody-based molecular imaging strategies and theranostic opportunities

snippets: Passive targeting of nanoparticles refers to the passive accumulation of nanoparticles in the tumor tissue, which is generally attributed to the enhanced permeability and retention effect.The concept of EPR was first introduced more than 30 years ago when Maeda and colleagues found that certain macromolecules accumulate preferentially in the tumor tissue (Matsumura et al., 1986).EPR is mainly the result of leakiness of the discontinuous endothelium of angiogenic tumor vasculature combined with defective lymphatic drainage of the tumor matrix, which facilitates the extravasation and accumulation of nanoparticles in tumor.It has been shown that the number of nanoparticles accumulated in tumor tissue may be 10-200 times higher than in normal tissue as a result of EPR.The EPR effect is considered to be the primary element to improve the efficacy and safety of nanotherapeutics.In fact, most of the nanomedicines marketed thus far base their increased therapeutic index mainly on the EPR effect [5]

The EPR effect is not effective for some cancers because of tumor heterogeneity and cancer stage, is even not applicable to some types of cancers, and it is not effective in some patients because of individual differences
It is manifest that blood cancers, very early stage tumors, and small metastasized cancers do not have or have only insignificant EPR effect.

snippets: Passive targeting to solid tumors can be achieved through the enhanced permeability and retention effect (EPR effect), as first described in the 1980s [13,14]. Pathological, pharmacological, and biochemical studies have shown that a solid tumor usually has such pathophysiological characteristics as hypervascularization, incomplete vascular architecture, and secretion of vascular permeability factors that stimulate extravasation and immaturity of lymphatic capillaries [15]. The tumor vasculature is characterized by a high proportion of proliferating endothelial cells, increased tortuosity, pericyte deficiency, and the formation of an atypical membrane. All this leads to rapid vascularization of the tumor, which is necessary to provide it with oxygen and nutrients and further proliferation. These characteristics make tumor blood vessels permeable to macromolecules. In addition, the lymphatic drainage system of the tumor functions ineffectively due to immature lymphatic capillaries; thus, nanocarriers are selectively preserved for a long period in the interstitial tissue of the tumor [15]. Numerous studies have shown that the EPR effect induces passive accumulation of macromolecules and micelles in solid tumors, enhancing the therapeutic effect while reducing side effects. It was also found that in most human tumors the effective pore size in the vasculature ranges from 200 to 600 nm in diameter, which allows passive targeting of tumors [16]. It was noted that the secretion of various factors such as nitric oxide, prostaglandins, bradykinin, and the main growth factor of fibroblasts in tumor tissues and overexpression of genes (such as vascular permeability factor or vascular endothelial growth factor) cause hyperpermeability of tumor microvessels. However, let us note that vascular permeability in the tumor changes with its progression and depends on the type of tumor and its anatomical location.
